articles.headline: Starting Over at 55
articles.snippet: Many people over age 55 are getting a second wind and starting their own business — often for the excitement or to make ends meet.   But success isn’t guaranteed.
articles.abstract: Many people over age 55 are getting a second wind and starting their own business — often for the excitement or to make ends meet.   But success isn’t guaranteed.
articles.lead_paragraph: AFTER 24 years as a marketing manager for Coors, Cinde Dolphin knew what was coming — Miller and Coors had just merged their United States beer operations, and hundreds of jobs were sure to be eliminated.

articles.headline: Developing Nations Setting Torrid Pace for Mergers
articles.snippet: This year, $135 billion, or 34 percent, of takeover deals have been linked to companies in the developing world.
articles.abstract: This year, $135 billion, or 34 percent, of takeover deals have been linked to companies in the developing world.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — As both companies and countries in the West and Japan stumble under debt and fear, a new enthusiasm for deals has already emerged this year in India, China and other developing countries.
articles.byline: By Heather Timmons and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Matching Life Experience With New Careers
articles.snippet: Many emerging jobs are are a natural fit for older people looking for new career opportunities.
articles.abstract: Many emerging jobs are are a natural fit for older people looking for new career opportunities.
articles.lead_paragraph: HEALTH navigator? Conflict coach? Pollution mitigation outreach worker? These emerging jobs aren’t household terms yet, but they are a natural fit for older people looking for new career opportunities, said Phyllis Segal, vice president at Civic Ventures, a nonprofit research group based in San Francisco.

articles.headline: Ads Posted on Facebook Strike Some as Off-Key
articles.snippet: From mainstream companies to others that are more off-putting, advertisers on Facebook are a motley bunch.
articles.abstract: From mainstream companies to others that are more off-putting, advertisers on Facebook are a motley bunch.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook, the world’s biggest social network, is selling more ad spots to big companies like Wal-Mart Stores, Procter & Gamble and PepsiCo.

articles.headline: Murky Candidacy Stokes Iraq’s Sectarian Fears
articles.snippet: As early voting began Thursday in Iraq, a Shiite once accused of running death squads is on the ballot.
articles.abstract: As early voting began Thursday in Iraq, a Shiite once accused of running death squads is on the ballot.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A politician widely accused of running death squads might not be expected to have an easy time running for public office.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Concerns Over ‘Metal on Metal’ Hip Implants
articles.snippet: Studies show that in some cases the devices can quickly begin to wear, generating metallic debris with effects that include groin pain, death of tissue in the hip joint and loss of surrounding bone.
articles.abstract: Studies show that in some cases the devices can quickly begin to wear, generating metallic debris with effects that include groin pain, death of tissue in the hip joint and loss of surrounding bone.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of the nation’s leading orthopedic surgeons have reduced or stopped use of a popular category of artificial hips amid concerns that the devices are causing severe tissue and bone damage in some patients, often requiring replacement surgery within a year or two.

articles.headline: White House Offers Bill to Restrict Big Banks’ Actions
articles.snippet: The legislation would ban some banks from investing in hedge funds or private equity funds and from making trades not for the benefit of their customers.
articles.abstract: The legislation would ban some banks from investing in hedge funds or private equity funds and from making trades not for the benefit of their customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration put forward legislation on Wednesday to rein in the size and scope of the nation’s largest banks. But the proposal faces strong resistance in Congress, where lawmakers have shown little appetite for adding to the prolonged debate on overhauling financial regulations.

articles.headline: Traders Seek Out the Next Greece in an Ailing Europe
articles.snippet: As Greece pledged anew to rein in its budget deficit, traders weighed the risks and potential rewards posed by the debts of other European governments.
articles.abstract: As Greece pledged anew to rein in its budget deficit, traders weighed the risks and potential rewards posed by the debts of other European governments.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is Spain the next Greece? Or Italy? Or Portugal?
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: Trusted Adviser or Stock Pusher? Finance Bill May Not Settle It
articles.snippet: The idea to make brokers fiduciaries who have a responsibility to put their customers’ interests first may not survive in the financial overhaul bill.
articles.abstract: The idea to make brokers fiduciaries who have a responsibility to put their customers’ interests first may not survive in the financial overhaul bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: You have probably seen the television commercial, the one where you seem to be watching an intimate conversation between family members. But at the end, you learn that the conversation was actually between a broker and his client.
